content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												The Yawhg is an interesting, if short, choose-your-own-adventure style game. It isn't difficult, but a lot of the game feels arbitrary and over-simple. It is definitely best as a multiplayer experience where four friends decide the fate of the (beautifully illustrated) characters. The soundtrack, while small, is breathtaking, and the illustrations are wonderful. If only it felt me like I had control of the outcome, and if only it went on for more than six turns a game, I would be the game's biggest fan, but it is short, sweet and more than a little random. I still recommend it, provided you can get it on sale so you don't pay ten whole bucks for such a short experience.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												This game has absolutely gorgeous art, and very charming writing. My first playthroughs, I was a bit frustrated about why I kept getting bad endings. But I've learned to be tactical with my choices, and I loved seeing the different ways that events will unfold.When it comes to the price-value ratio, I'm slightly biased becaused I'm a huge fan of Emily Carroll's work. That means I was kindly inclined towards this game to start with. But, let's look at it this way -- where I live, movie tickets cost $12, for an hour and a half, to two hours plus of entertainment. I paid $10 for this game, and got an hour and half of multiple playthroughs, where I explored a fascinating fantasy world. I'm okay with that, and I'm sure I'll come back to this game later, just to experience that world again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												This is an unique kind of party game that you don't find anywhere else. Rather than a party game where you have mindless fun and game, this is a game where you and your friends take on a role and roleplay together. As such, it is a really good roleplay game, where all of the actions have direct or/and indirect consequences and changes the outcome of the game. With every playthrough, every decision and consequences differs, and so every playthrough is unique in it's own way. The art-style is nice, the music (albeit repetitive) suits the mood, the gameplay is simple and engaging, and when played with friends, i have no doubt that it'll be a fun party game, possibly even better when drunk.As a single player game however, it completely lacks any kind of weight. This is the reason why i cannot recommend this to anyone who does not have a friend to play couch co-op with, because that is the only way this game is meant to be played. 0.2 hours is all that it takes for me to finish one playthrough, and that's with me reading every single text. It's really short, really shallow as well, and does not leave a lasting impression. Like i mentioned before, this game is meant to be played with other people, who will contribute their own depths to the story. Playing it alone however, means that there's nothing much to do, except absentmindedly pick choices and read the consequences, alone.I want to love this game, because this kind of game with choices, branching story, consequences that impacts the story, and character building, but there's not enough for me to love about this gameTL;DR if you have someone to go couch co-op with, i would recommend buying it. If you don't have, don't buy this.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												The Yawhg is a choice-based adventure where you must select a character and await the arrival of the deadly Yawhg.I played a little over 80 minutes, and thoroughly enjoyed the game. First, let's discuss it's strengths.The Yawhg is beautiful. The artwork is all fantastic and fits the theme of the game perfectly. The music and soundtrack of the game is haunting and wonderful. The gameplay is interesting and, at first, exciting. The story is enjoyable and satisfying. And now, the negative sides of the game. It's short. Not such a bad thing, but when coupled with the retail price, the sense of worth is a little low. I got 80 minutes of gameplay out of the game, which I did enjoy, though the price is a little high for my taste.  Next up, again, the gameplay. After one or two playthroughs of the game, the mechanics are no longer exciting as you can kind of see what's happening quite easily, meaning completion of the game can be easily "gamed" (if you know what I mean). The game also lacks achievements. Woah woah wait, that's not a bad thing right? Actually, I think in this case, it is. Achievements mean nothing, it's true, but I think, had The Yawhg had achievements, it would have added a heck of a lot more replayability as the achievements could direct your play, asking you to complete sub-stories, professions, and multiple side ideas which, after completion, many will not revisit.Either way, a really charming and lovely game. I enjoyed it thoroughly.Nilesy

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												20 minutes, are about how long one would need to finish a playthrough of The Yawhg.It's not going to rock your world-view or revolutionize RPG genre. But it's the most calming game I have played in a long long time: you are given 6 rounds of free will, in the forms of overworld map and discrete choices, and all you get in returns are artworks and narrations. This is interactive equivalent of a good bedtime novel.No button smashing, puzzle solving or timer countdown. Just you and your simple decisions. For some it's not worth the 9.99 USD, for me, it distills the very core of my interests: game narrative and mechanics.Even if you are unsure about it's short playthrough (and possible repetitiveness), try to get it on sales, and enjoy what The Yawhg has to offer.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												This game...I really find myself enjoying these short non-traditional games that are more like interactive books, more and more. This one is in the vein of choose your own adventure, ah my childhood, and does a great job at mixing up your choices and making the consequences matter. It hard to say too much about the game is its so short, spoiling how it plays out seems unfair.   You basically can play 1 to 4 people, though you can play any of that amount also by yourself.  You have 8 days to choose what to do. There's 8 to 10 locations in the town and each has 1 of 2 activities.  These don't change but the outcome are highly random and you will have to make choices during each daily action that has a stat effect then and one on the overall outcome of the game.  Its brillant, and the music is hauntingly beautiful with it as some of the heart wrenching, funny outcomes.  The fact that i played though it twice in 30 minutes shouldn't disuade you from playing it.  I had a 75% off coupon which is why i bought it today but i think i could still recommend it whole heartedly at much closer to its actually asking price.  The fact that you can replay it many times over and might be a cool "game" to play with non-gamer friends or family is kinda a vaulable thing.Like all good games with choices it has sweet epilogues for each characters as well.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												I worked hard at all the tasks I performed in my life. Be it landscaping the park, chopping wood in the forest, or fighting in the arena, I labored hard to succeed. Through hard work, I was able to sharpen my mind alongside my body; leaving me prepared on the fateful day in the arena. The great demon was fierce, but my self-confidence was fiercer. With one mighty blow, I ended what my companion could not. But, now, I am not so sure I ended up the victor. The public hails me as a hero that banished the demon, but I am no longer confident the demon was truly banished. I suspect the struggle has only begun.I may not have the strength.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												Everyone grab a drink and gather around the couch; it's time to play The Yawhg.In the vast sea of choose-your-own-adventure games out there, why are so few multiplayer? Why do so many forego gorgeous illustrations and lovingly hand-lettered title cards for plain black-on-white text? Why do so few have the brief playtime that makes for a perfect party game? Why do none of them have you cast the deciding vote in an election for a rat president?The Yawhg succeeds on all of these fronts. It's also solidly, but not perfectly replayable (as you'll run into many events again on repeat plays). I only wish that there were more cooperative CYOAs like it. Developers, take note.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												For all the flack and negative reviews "choose your own adventure" books get, I still love them.  Heck, I wanted to write one when I was in first grade!  The Yawhg takes the CYOA formula and spins it on its head by delivering a dynamic story in a way only an electronic source could.  Each playthrough is different and fresh, compelling you to restart as soon as it ends.  Additionally, the ability to play with friends will result in the type of laughter and cheers only brought about on a board game night.  Fun, beautiful, and very charming.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												This is such a fantastic game! Don't you dare be put off by the low price or the people saying it's too short. This is a game that one can simply stop playing.It has a fun, comedy board game style that will make you nostalgic and feel happy. The music is beautiful, and to top all that off there's the one unique point of this game that is done so well:It's not about getting to the end, it's about enjoying what you have whilst you still have it. That, my friends, is a fantastic message about life. You're playing a fable! You simply don't lose the game. Now, people will play it for different reasons. At first, you play it to make sure there's a good ending. Overtime, you get this idea that actually it's not about that. You make moral choices, you choose your fate. What your character becomes is a reflection of how you play it, and trust me, there's some really great twists and turns to the game.My favourite part is that what one player does directly influences what happens to the other, thus making it a team game. Play with your friends, play with yourself, it's fun both ways for different reasons. Top game of the season, game of the year so far for me. So, what are you waiting for? Buy it!

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												I've always been partial to choose your own adventures. The Yawhg is an interactive story with an amazing soundtrack even if it only features a couple of songs. It provides a huge variety of random events so that each playthrough is a fresh new experience. Each game is pretty short with only 6 turns to the arrival of the titular Yawhg after which your choices will reflect the outcome in the aftermath of the Yawhg's destruction. You may play up to four characters at a time, with friends or alone. My only disappointment in this is that the 'multiplayer' option is only local not online.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												An experience worth having with others. On your own, it's nothing special. With others around, the whole "do I look after myself at the expense of everyone else, or do we work together for the best chance of survival?" question comes in to play.Have a couple of drinks handy, set it up on a big TV with a couple of controllers and cheer on each other's successes - or laugh at their misfortunes.For ten bucks at around 10-30 minutes a play-through, it's a solid night in.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												This game is incredibly story-driven, yet the relative lack of gameplay doesn't take away from the experience. The player still has to think through difficult decisions, sometimes without a right answer to choose from, and the story varies every time it's played. You could make bad decisions early on that affect the whole playthrough, you could ignore your stats and end up with a useless character, or the game could just hate you and force you to fail. Any one of those can give you leeches.Everyone hates the leeches, yet it can be the funniest occurence in the game.I'm not going to spoil anything in this (Says he after warning of leeches), but you can fail, succeed or survive, all of which are based on decisions you make during the initial six weeks and after the Yawhg. You can control the outcome, but sometimes you have to take a chance, do something different, and see what happens.WARNING: This game will either draw you in or make you hate it. I cannot, nor can anyone else, guarantee that you will enjoy it. It's one of those games. Consider yourself warned.I have been anticipating Steam release since this game was launched last year. I very nearly bought it when it was made known that it probably wouldn't make it, but I waited and it arrived. Meanwhile, I have watched hours of gameplay. Yeah, it probably ruined a few of the surprises for me, but I don't mind. I still haven't seen close to all of the endings.---Basically: Get the game, but make sure to watch gameplay videos first. You may regret buying it without doing so first. It's just that kind of game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												A very good party game that's great for developing emergent stories - like the tale of a humble woodcutter who became known for punching fists until they broke, gave to charity, and fought crime, the story of a simple man who kept getting♥♥♥♥♥♥on by life and ended up giving much of his wealth to help his city before living out an entirely ordinary life, or the gadabout socialite who made a million friends and got absolutely nowhere at the end of her life, becoming a drunk instead of contributing to society.It does NOT really work as a single player game, however.  You really need at least one other player for the game to truly take off, and it works best with a full set.  The joy comes out of everyone's choices and motivations and goals bouncing off everyone else's and providing contrast - puppetmastering everyone for some kind of optimal result just isn't that interesting.  Shame it's local multiplayer only, then, but given how complex netcode can be, it's understandable.In short, get this game if you can drag at least one friend in to play with you in real life.  Otherwise, it's much more hit-or-miss.

Personally, I believe this game should be played with others, just to see what different conclusions you all can achieve. It's a fun first-time group game. My friends and I had a blast when we played it but I don't think it'll be something we'll repeat anytime soon. --- Unless of course they add an expansion pack adding assortment of new endings and scenarios.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Works like a choose your own adventure book and can be played locally with 1-4 players. It works well with four players at once though. Players choose their own characters and decide what to do with their time before a devastating storm called the Yawhg hits the city. This leads to each character having a unique story during the game. I've played about 5 or 6 times and had different results each round. My only complaint is that each game is too short. content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												The Yawhg is a fantastic choose-your-own-adventure game in which you controll two-to-four characters in their final weeks before the "Yawhg" arrives.  Each time you play, the story which unfolds is randomized allowing a vast array of different events and outcomes to happen.  It is an anjoyable game on your own, but even more so with others, each controling their own character.  The setting is a unique fantasy world whith many unsettling and amazing wonders.  The "Yawhg" is inevitable, but will you be able to save the town from the aftermath of it's destruction?

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This game is about multiple playthroughs of short games. It reminds me of FTL in that manner, but much more stripped down.Despite its replayability, it still could be considered a very short lived experience.It requires a couple of things I'd hope to see in a patch.First, Online Co-Op, though I'm sure they are aware of that.Second, being a Visual Novel at heart, it could really use a 'skip seen text' button, like most include.Third, Achievements. In-game challenges and rewards would be ideal, something like FTL has, but even just some steam achievements would really make this game. Usually they're just slapped on and add nothing, but this game could really use something to drive you to see more content. It's really easy to just play a few games, and then lose all the initiative to keep going. A few Goals so that you're not just meandering around town would be really nice.Right now I'm trying to destroy as many places in a single game as I can.Even just % content seen counter would add a lot.So, to truly recommend it needs just a slight patch. Being a little cheaper wouldn't go amiss either.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												This is such a fantastic game! Don't you dare be put off by the low price or the people saying it's too short. This is a game that one can simply stop playing.It has a fun, comedy board game style that will make you nostalgic and feel happy. The music is beautiful, and to top all that off there's the one unique point of this game that is done so well:It's not about getting to the end, it's about enjoying what you have whilst you still have it. That, my friends, is a fantastic message about life. You're playing a fable! You simply don't lose the game. Now, people will play it for different reasons. At first, you play it to make sure there's a good ending. Overtime, you get this idea that actually it's not about that. You make moral choices, you choose your fate. What your character becomes is a reflection of how you play it, and trust me, there's some really great twists and turns to the game.My favourite part is that what one player does directly influences what happens to the other, thus making it a team game. Play with your friends, play with yourself, it's fun both ways for different reasons. Top game of the season, game of the year so far for me. So, what are you waiting for? Buy it!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												This game in and of itself is fun. Sure, some things get a little repetitive since there's only so many dialogue options once things get rolling, but the game itself is fine. What I was not aware of, however, was that this game is in a fixed resolution and sound quality. What does that mean?? You can't change the resolution and you can't lower or raise the sound. And this is actually a big deal. One of the main draws of the game is using locations around the town to better your stats and wealth before the Yawhg comes. Sounds pretty easy, just have to make some tough decisions. Which is fine. It's good. Except that depending on your monitor, you can't see your base or upgraded stats. And that causes kinks when you actually progress past Week 6, and things get a little more interesting.While over all the lack of different resolutions is mostly cosmetic, it is something to consider and think about before purchasing this game. And if I had known that there weren't any resolution options before I bought it, I wouldn't have spent my money on it.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Pros-Cute Graphics.-The concept is good (execution is poor)-Interesting but really random outcomes.Cons-The game literally is a few minutes long. NO WAY IT IS WORTH $10. I got it on sale for $4.99 and I admittedly feel I got the short end of this deal.-Went for an artsy soundtrack but really it is just annoying.-Don't really see any replay value since the game is like 10 mins long (if you drag it out) and none of the choices really matter it is pretty random. I felt no investment in the story or what happened at all.------------------It could be so so much more but honestly you answer like 6 questions it doesn't really matter how and the game is pretty much done. Then it tells you what the end outcome is (Your character becomes the best potion brewer in the world but never figures out how to brew a love potion). Would be nice if it was longer and actually made you invest in what happens and if there was any strategy or some point to the game, as it is it is like 6 random choices and you don't even care what happens, at least I didn't care.I love indie games and the concept of this one could have really been fun and amazing instead it feels like it is completely unfinished and has basically no point and little to no replay value.No idea how this got so many good reviews. I feel bad leaving a negative review because I am sure the producers are good people and I can see how the concept would work if it was fleshed out but I was just really, really disappointed.Lot of better games out there for $10 or $5 bucks, try those instead.Also steam made me play this game like 5 times in a row to register that I had played for 5 mins and could leave a review. Le Sigh... Now I really know there isn't a whole lot of replayability.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												While rich in story and offering many different stories to be told for up to 4 players, Yawhg still seems to fall short of the game that it could have potentially been. The game is essentially for 1-4 players, each taking their turn of where to go during the week, what to do at said location, and how you respond to a random event. This process lasts for several weeks, around 6 or 8 I believe, before the "Yawhg" comes. After the Yawhg comes, the game sums up your ending randomly. While fun, witty, and comedic, the "adventure" that players go through is drastically short and is merely based on week to week events rather than the accumulative story. For $9.99 I would say the game is extremely short (lasting around 5-15 minutes depending on how fast you can read) and I would recommend it as a nice steam summer sale pick up. Other positive notes include pretty artwork, interesting scenarios, and a short-lived entertaining adventure game. I would give it a 5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												This is not a game.This is a very, very, very shallow choose your own adventure book. With some pictures.While I have no qualms with "playing" visual novels, or other game mediums where interactivity is minimal, those experiences at least make up with a very large amount of narration, music or other aesthetic devices. The Yawhg is not like those things. The Yawhg is closest to a board game, not a visual novel, but as a board game it offers no real interactivity. Your choices are reduced to spending time in a small amount of locations, for a small amount of turns. What you do can only affect others through accidental results, so there's no strategy involved. Your choices only affect a small slide of endings, which are a very small range from totally failing to fix a town, to... fixing a town completely.After your second or third playthrough, you'll realize there's no game to speak of. You tally small amounts of arbitrary points and once you know which location benefits which points, you've figured out all there is to the game. Whether you repair the town or not depends entirely on the whims of individual players, as players can't affect the choices of others in any planned way. At the end, all those arbitrary stat points are "added" in an effective or ineffective way, and if the points cross a certain threshold, you get a specific ending.And... that's it. Even tic-tac-toe or checkers offers more interactivity.This is not a multiplayer game. The basic aspect of strategic reasoning is that the choices of others affect yours. This does not happen here, at least not on account of a player's agency. There is no reason to return to The Yawhg once you figure out how it works. And I believe even small children can figure that out in less than an hour.Avoid this "game". It's not even worth playing it for free. It's a completely shallow experience. It's only grace is that it serves as a great example of something that -looks- like a game, but is not. In that, it's a great lesson in game design: what -not- to do.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												What fascinates me about this game is that each event that happens to one of your characters has no/little inherent significance - the power of each event and the narrative as a whole is whatever the player reads into the sequence.I've had a doctor character lose faith in herself after a failure lead to the deaths of multiple townsfolk, only to regain her confidence out of necessity when the town needs her. I've had a rich socialite who cares for nobody but himself spiral into a depression after seeing the horrors that the Yawhg results in. None of these narratives are explicit - I am able to give them their own stories based upon these modular events that the game is constructed from. A strangely large amount of fun, and fascinating at that.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												The term "Visual Novel" is usually an annoying term to read in a review. But, The Yawhg is without a doubt a visual storytelling experience that anyone who enjoys 'choose your own adventure' novels or games will love. The gameplay is minimal, you choose two to four characters (best suited for multiplayer, maybe) and choose where they will spend their single week of six. In these six weeks, the Yawhg, a mythical beast who never shows it's face to the player, will attack the town and destroy everything you've become familiar with. Because the actual weeks pass by in maybe 15 minutes, multiple playthoughs are a must. And hard to resist. You can choose to spread out your experience, attacking everything to do, or you can grind out your magic, charm, mind, and so forth at one location six weeks in a row. However, the multiple endings find a way to beat your system faster than you learned to cheat theirs. Spending time bartending for charm, you end up an alcoholic, dead from your own love. Grinding out magic at the alchemist tower leaves you alone, without love, and left to create potions to satisfy your only happiness. This is where the Yawhg becomes a "beautiful" experience. Albeit depressing, the levels of endings you can receive give you a feeling that you did what needed to be done. There is no need for guides, builds, playing a game the way you don't usually play just so you can have a completionist ending or a successful character stat build. This is a game that is relentless in experience that you learn on your own, and that you can only experience if you treat it like a real week by week lifestyle. This is your story to create, and it's a doozy.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												The yawhg as a game is very much like a board game. Every day you gather stats by visiting many locations of the city, with an immense amount of different things that can happen.  After 6 weeks you choose what you want to do with those skills you`ve garnered, and depending on them, you decide the towns fate.The main meat of the game however are the immense amount of different endings. You might have angered someone you shouldn`t have during the 6 weeks. You might have decided to do something you really shouldn`t have at the end. Maybe you turn into a monster yourself! ...Or maybe you live mostly an ordinary life. The game in itself is best when played as a group. The game allows up to 4 players to go live in the town. The games biggest downfall is the fact, that it doesn`t support online multiplayer, but that is easily fixed with a call with skype as one person reads the choices out loud and does the choices for the other players like a game master.Overall, if you want a fun experience, which most likely gives you an unique ending everytime if you aren`t afraid to try something new, and you like reading, buy the game.

												As far as setting a mood through music, storytelling, pacing, the logic of choices and consequences, and the juxtaposition of looming disaster to the characters' blythely going about their lives, the game is simultaneously funny, poignant and a little chilling. In short, this game hits all the right notes in attempting what it aims to do. It's short enough that you can get through the whole thing in one sitting and immediately want to do it all over again to try different scenarios; it's also just long enough that it feels as though what you decide has some impact on the world and you can even see some far-reaching, unexpected consequences down the line. It's deceptively complex, and brilliant in its simplicity.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												This game is great for a group of friends who love playing games together.The Yawhg is not your average multiplayer game, however. It is sort of a multiplayer choose-your-own-adventure game. Each person chooses a character and then chooses where they want to spend one of their 6 weeks before the Yawhg arrives. The beuty lies in the amount of variation you can get therein. Will you stay at the bar and get drunk all week? Will you go to the palace and dance the nights away? Will you don a mask and fight crime in the back alleys for the slums? All these options are available to you.After choosing what you will be doing that week, a small story is told to you for that week, maybe while fighting crime you meet someone who turns you into a vampire! Maybe during your work at the hospital hundreds of leeches break free! While they are limited, the story elements of each location are different from each other and highly entertaining. During the story part, your stats will change (Physique, Mind, Magic, Finesse, etc). These will be important after the Yawhg arrives.The most interesting thing about the story elements is that they have a chance of crossing over to other areas. If the aformentioned leeches break free from the hospital, they may spill over into the slums! Or maybe even the lake! The dryad you met in the woods may show up in the arena! The combinations are truely interesting and make the game even more fun to explore.After the Yawhg arrives, you are tasked to rebuild by taking on one of many important (or not so important) roles around the town. Will you band the remaning townsfolk together and lead? Will you try to use your might to build? Will you use your magical aptitued to brew potions? Beware, though, because if you do not have the proper stats (gained from the story parts of the game) you will fail in your attempt to help, and you will hinder the rebuilding.After everyone has chosen a role they are given their last story segment and you are told if the town will press on after the Yawhg or if it will ultimately fall to ruin.I would like to see more stories added or mod support so that the community could add their own stories.The game is overall fun for a group of friends, and trying to get the best ending can be challanging and a true team effort. I would highly reccomend this game with 2 or 3 friends that are will to experiment in gameplay and work together.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												For those who enjoy board games, the Yawhg feels familiar. Averything happen in turns and random events, shaping your character's evolution and leading to their sucess or failure at the conclusion.Things to keep in mind if you want to buy this game:1- It's really short. Really, really short. Takes about 7 turns to finish one gameplay.Then you get the conclusion and can start again. Since events are random, you'll probably find new things when playing for the second (and third, fourth, etc) time, but things start to repeat soon.2- It's best if played with friends. Not online, but at your side, using the same computer. You can have up to four players and I could only have real fun with The Yawhg after I invited others to play with me. Like I said before, very similar to a board game.With that in mind, chances are you won't be surprised and will end up having fun. The visuals and songs are really well done too. It's not worth a lot of money and I think would be best as a Ipad game, but it's a nice idea. Not for everyone, though. Makes me wish they would release an expansion, with more events, locations, etc. As it is now, I fear is way too short and might get repetitive too soon. Still, I had fun, and that's what counts.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												I wish the game had more substance but the art and writing keep it from blending into other games like this. First off, no online co op mode, which is weird to want but this would have been perfect for my friends and I to play over skype. The game gives you four characters to choose from, all very unique and different. You have six weeks before this "Yawhg" decends onto the world. Each turn you get to choose where your character decides to spend their week. Once you make a choice you then choose between two paths and two paths again, you get text for what your character does within these branching paths but this is the formula it sticks with. You gain (or lose) stats depending on your decisions. Once the six weeks are up the Yawhg appears and you have some choices after it does appear. At this point your characters stats and your own choice determine whether the characters and towns fate is positive or negative. For the price I can't complain, I really need to try some of the other paths. It's definitely unique and something you won't get all too often.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												This game is great for a group of friends who love playing games together.The Yawhg is not your average multiplayer game, however. It is sort of a multiplayer choose-your-own-adventure game. Each person chooses a character and then chooses where they want to spend one of their 6 weeks before the Yawhg arrives. The beuty lies in the amount of variation you can get therein. Will you stay at the bar and get drunk all week? Will you go to the palace and dance the nights away? Will you don a mask and fight crime in the back alleys for the slums? All these options are available to you.After choosing what you will be doing that week, a small story is told to you for that week, maybe while fighting crime you meet someone who turns you into a vampire! Maybe during your work at the hospital hundreds of leeches break free! While they are limited, the story elements of each location are different from each other and highly entertaining. During the story part, your stats will change (Physique, Mind, Magic, Finesse, etc). These will be important after the Yawhg arrives.The most interesting thing about the story elements is that they have a chance of crossing over to other areas. If the aformentioned leeches break free from the hospital, they may spill over into the slums! Or maybe even the lake! The dryad you met in the woods may show up in the arena! The combinations are truely interesting and make the game even more fun to explore.After the Yawhg arrives, you are tasked to rebuild by taking on one of many important (or not so important) roles around the town. Will you band the remaning townsfolk together and lead? Will you try to use your might to build? Will you use your magical aptitued to brew potions? Beware, though, because if you do not have the proper stats (gained from the story parts of the game) you will fail in your attempt to help, and you will hinder the rebuilding.After everyone has chosen a role they are given their last story segment and you are told if the town will press on after the Yawhg or if it will ultimately fall to ruin.I would like to see more stories added or mod support so that the community could add their own stories.The game is overall fun for a group of friends, and trying to get the best ending can be challanging and a true team effort. I would highly reccomend this game with 2 or 3 friends that are will to experiment in gameplay and work together.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												This game has some flaws but is also just brilliant.First off the lack of settings (like turning down volume or monitor settings) and several typos (for example switching "he" and "she" on occasion) are slight annoyances.It is also quite easy to figure out a "winning" strategy which gets you the "flourishing" ending almost every time. This would make the game very boring, if that were actually relevant, which it isn't.This is where the game's brilliant aspects come in. The random events through the game provide witty, at times completely unexpected (and being genuinely surprised is something I very rarely experience in games) and simply hilarious moments. You will find yourself just playing through the game (which takes less than 30 minutes in single player) time and time again trying to discover new random events, possible outcomes and resulting consequences. And then there is the ending. All your choices tying together to decide the fate of the village, followed by (perhaps more importantly) the conclusion of each character's own story based on the chosen tasks and random events, once more providing several outcomes to be discovered.In this regard this game, with it's "choose your own adventure" feeling despite the preset timeline, is exactly what alot of the bigger RPG titles are lacking realized on a smaller stage.Expecially the multiplayer (which is limited to hot seat, but quite frankly a online multiplayer wouldn't make sense anyway) adds even more excitement and laughter to the game. If you have the option it is very rewarding.All this combined with a lovely animation and very soothing soundtrack in my opinion make this game most definetely worth the time and money.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												"This game is too short." "This game doesn't run on my PC." "This game breaks when I alt-tab." "This game crashes sometimes for no reason." "This game doesn't work with my monitor and cuts off the edges hurting playability." "Local co-op only is terrible for PC."How could I recommend a game where all of the above can be true depending on your system and beliefs?I even encounter some of these problems and I still play A LOT of this game.Because...the game is very very good. Seriously. Yes it only takes 10-20 minutes to run through the game, but the game is setup to be played many times. It is amazing the amount of depth they have managed to achieve with such simple design. This game is an art piece. When it works, it works very well. It is beautiful visually with excellent art choices for the still images. The soundtrack is fantastic with the same song managing to convey both happiness in the good endings and sadness in the bad endings and even horror in a rare combination of events. The mechanics are simple, intuitive, and very effective.The crashes are frustrating, but I'd say they only happen 7% of the time. At least in my case. My family has recieved more enjoyment out of this $10 purchase then they would in a far more expensive movie purchase. I'd say if you are willing to risk the possibility of the problems I listed at the start don't hesitate; pick this up immediately. The developer is active as well and many of the issues may be resolved soon if they are not already.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												This game is really fun and produces hours of fun with your friends or on your own, getting a different story ending every time you play. This is thanks to "The Yawhg"'s multiple choice "choose your story" gameplay. Another great thing about this game is how each action you complete has an effect on a friend you are playing with. [SPOILER AHEAD!!!] For example, if you fail to stop the leaches escaping the hospital, they will infest the pond in the gardens and potentially harm another player. The Yawhg also contains a "stats system" which gives it a more "Strategy/RPG" feel while you're playing. [SPOILER AHEAD!!!] These stats are important for the end of the game when you choose your new role in the community of your destroyed town.All in all, i have no negative comments on this game and think it is absoloutely brilliant for such a simple and small game made by so few people. Well worth the £6.99 i paid!!!

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Where to start?I bought this game months ago, I hadn't heard anything about it but after taking a look at the description at the store I figured I'd give it a try. It's a short game, a regular playthrough might take you about 15 minutes or less, but it has one of the highest replay values I've ever seen in a game. It's one of those games where your decisions matter but it's more like a "Choose your own adventure" book turned into a game. Depending on what you do you will get different endings, but getting a good ending for your town doesn't necesarily mean that the characters you use will get a good ending and viceversa. But even when your characters get a good ending there might be something bittersweet about it.The art style is beautiful and the soundtrack is great. The main theme is one of the most haunting songs I've heard in ages. I totally recommend it.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												If I had to sum the general feeling of The Yawhg up in one word, it would probably have to be “poignant”. On the surface it's a clever, succinct and skilfully woven series of actions, reactions and consequences. The art style is whimsical enough to temper the sometimes brooding prose and the music treads the line between contemplative and melancholic. It's funny and twisted and thoughtful, often all at the same time. For so brief a game, it really pulls you in. Upon nearing the finish you grow acutely aware of the weight of your actions, and the impact your decisions have had on the characters you’ve encountered. The desire to change the outcomes of your latest play-through will compel you to keep coming back. It’s a beautifully made and artfully executed “what if?” trap. For those still looking for the perfect outcome, something tells me there’s no such thing in The Yawhg. But then again, I guess that’s kind of the point?

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												This is a stunning game. I'm a great fan of miss Carroll's work and rushed to buy this as soon as it was out. Not only the art is gorgeous, but the writing and music are fantastic! Sure, it feels a bit short, but even that makes me reward The Yawhg with some longing. The story left my heart aching, yearning to know more about these characters who aren't named - but feel fully fledged in Carroll's art. It's amazing how the varying drawings give them a sense of self despite the way you might choose how to play them. Still, I understand how it serves the purpose of the storytelling here not to give a deep insight into their lives "prior" the Yawhg... Which doesn't make me stop wanting to read more stories into this world. It's fascinating how this short game made me feel so many things - I'd kill for Emily Carroll to draw or write more about this, even in form of comics!For those who complain about the price, yes, it's a short game, but it's a short game that manages to pack much more meaning in 10 minutes of gameplay than some do in 42h+

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												For those who love an interesting narrative and playing games with friends, the Yawhg offers a unique experience that I have found to be very memborable. While the game can be played alone controlling multiple characters, it is best with friends. There  are some very creative stories within this, that I definitely do not want to spoil. A wonderful soundtrack and gorgeous art complement the 'choose your own adventure' gameplay.The biggest question for you will be is it worth the price? I have played the game four times now (roughly 30 minutes per playthrough) and have seen some repeated stories (but not always the same outcome!) but have enjoyed every time. The Steam release makes me want to play it again. For such a memborable experience, I say it's definitely worth the price. If you are unsure, how about check out the start of a playthrough (I have one linked below) but don't watch too much, as the best part of this game is experiencing it for yourself!My friends and I filmed a whole playthrough of the Yawhg, the first episode is available here:

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												The Yawhg is, let's be honest, an experiment in creating a multiplayer version of those raise-stat type story games.  This doesn't mean it's bad - it's quite good - but know what you're getting into when you buy it.  Basically it's a smart visual novel game for parties.Two to four characters make choices, lead lives, and prepare as a strange threat - the Yawhg - approaches.  Doing things raises character stats and affects other elements of the game.  A magical experiment, a won gladiatorial event, an undifused bomb, all affect other characters.  When the disaster does happen, characters then choose their path after, which affects the end of the game.Gameplay is pretty short - the game is meant to be replayed.  Graphics are decent, and the storybook look really works.  Music is great.So the question on buying it is "do you want an experimental multiplayer story game."  If you do, this is for you.  Otherwise, its not for you - but I consider it a good game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												The Yawgh is a fun "Choose-Your-Own-Adventure"-type game in which you can control 2-4 characters in a town for 6 weeks as well as build up different character stats which also affect the story.What I Did Like: The story was well-written and entertaining, including all the different story options. It's nice they didn't always make it terribly obvious what was going to happen or what stats you would need in order to have a 'successful' result when making a choice. I liked the art and loved the music.What I Didn't Like: Each play-through is pretty quick, even using all 4 characters - about 10-15 minutes. After 45 minutes of playing, I felt I had seen 80% of the "event triggers" if that makes sense, and was ready to play something else for the time being.Overall: I found the game to be really enjoyable as well as relaxing. I experienced maybe half of what the game has to offer, story-wise, and for me this definitely has replay value. Not a bad deal for $10 if you know you like "C-Y-O-A" and an even better deal if you can get it on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												The Yawhg is not a game you pick up to complete your indie collection or to sit fashionably next to your visual novels. Nor is it one you play for a story. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												I orignally saw Kim from the Yogscast play this game, and although I got the ending about "What the Yawhg actually is" ruined for me, I have played this already for a solid hour.Seeing as I already know what happens, I decided to get some friends in a skype call and get them to come on an adventure. Screensharing was not an option at that moment in time, as some of them were using their phones, but that did not take away from the fun and... odd enjoyment that we recieved whilst playing it.This game has fantastic music, which I fell in love with, and an art style which is hard not to instantly adore. Yes, this is a story based game with still images of what happens.. but this is NOT a bad thing.For seven pounds, I am finding so much content in this small gem of a game. If you have seven pounds lying around, then get this game. Do not hesitate in the slightest.If (or when) you decide to buy this game, do not forget that Emily Carrol has not written infinite possibilities of what could happen during a playthrough. Often, you'll come across an instance that you rememeber from your first playthrough, or your fifth, or tenth. However, this does not take away from the charm that this game has to offer.After two play throughs with a group of friends, they unleashed killer rats, deadly leeches and poisoned the towns water supply, all having effects throughout the week.A game like this should be enjoyed thoroughly, but in small doses. If you are fine with repeating occurances, then good on you, play this to your hearts content and find enjoyment in remebering the good and bad that WILL happen to you.However, if you are like myself, then it will be best to play this game once or twice every few weeks.I will never regret buying this game, even if I can memorise every occurance in every location.. SImply because of the feelings of satisfaction this game gave me.9.5/10 - Could be longer, but a definite worthwhile investment for anyone who wants something.. uniquely different and genuinely beautiful.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												A quirky and quaint little game.  The story lines are funny and rather strange, but that makes them interesting.  They can also be unexpectedly dark.  The art is very bright and colourful, and the music, though only two songs, is pleasant.  Most people complain about it being too short (each round is about 10 minutes), although I think it's meant to be that way so you can play multiple rounds quickly, seeing as it can be difficult to save the town when you're still new to the game.  I wish there was more variation, though; once you've played about 10 rounds, you've basically seen everything, and saving the town becomes quite easy.  There are some typos in the game (I think I spotted about two or three), which is a little disappointing given that it's primarily text-based.  Also, I can't seem to run the game in windowed mode, although I know not everyone has this problem.  You can't skip the credits at the end, although they only last about 15 seconds, so I don't think that's a big deal.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Some games are great for single player experiences, while others shine as a multiplayer experience. I've found that The Yawhg shines best at the latter. Don't get me wrong, I throughly enjoyed my single player time with the game and it can be played with just one person. I feel that The Yawhg really shines brightest when played with a group of people. Hearing your friends react to events in game is an absolute delight (unless said friends are jerks but you might wanna avoid such people). I recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a quick party game, or to anyone who enjoys the choose your own adventure games/books. It can be played with both a keyboard/mouse or a xbox 360 controller (not sure about other style game pads). I would recommend playing it with a controller if possible.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												A cute, yet very depressing little game created with hot-seat multi-playing in mind (sort of like a boardgame.) The story is simple, yet interesting enough to keep you enthralled. The game itself is very short, but it's replay value is very high (sort of like a board game.) Each choice you make within the game has randomized events so it won't play the same way twice. The game is very difficult to completely succeed and rewards co-op gmeplay. Get together and discuss your actions with each other for best results!Solo play = 8/10Group play = 9/10Co-op play = 10/10

												This simple yet complex indie game is probably one of my favorites. Mainly because the art style, and the theme song take the cake. But either way, this indie game, though very small, can leave quite an imprint on you. I recommend this game to anyone who is feeling down in the dumps and could use a big dose of happiness, but are also looking for quick and easy gameplay. All in all, I give it 10 leeches/10 leeches.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												After the 11 or so hours of playtime here, I guess I should review.So generally, The Yawhg seems to be a simplified (and short) version of DnD which impliments a more story-driven atmosphere. You have only so much time to enjoy the city before it is destroyed by the great Yawhg, then you must either fix or destroy what is around you in the survival effort. This is honestly one of the best games to play with your friends while streaming or otherwise sharing your screen on here. Due to the simplicity of it, there isn't any multiplayer for it (which isn't a bad thing) and forces you to either have more of a social environment in playing, or enjoy your time alone. The game feels and plays much better if you try to wrap yourself in the situation around you, however too many playthroughs in succession will become repetetive. There are many different things to do, however, and you WILL enjoy your time playing this.TL;DR: I r8 8/8 m8

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												I finished my first game in 10 minutes, so if this very short playing time doesn't interest you, maybe don't get this game. Every "week" is only one action, and you play as a minimum of two characters, each taking turns doing an action for a week. So, all in all, there's about 12 actions you make per game (with an amount of extra things that can happen during those actions based on your stats), and because of this, each playthrough isn't very long. It can be easy to sink an hour or so into this game (as you can probably see, I certainly have), but by the second or so playthrough it gets pretty easy to manipulate the game.I really like The Yawhg, but I need to make it known that liking the game is all based on each player's wants and needs in a good game.The Yawhg has really nice art, a unique soundtrack, interesting scenarios, great writing, and it's just all around a clever little indie game (unless you're oblivious like me and don't get it the first time around. Or the second. Or an hour later of playing).But it can be very short, and the four characters really don't offer anything in the way of personality- just well done, diverse physical design. The player wholly decides what the characters are like.I would say buy this game on sale. Because there's no variety in character attributes unless the variety is made (by the player), and the game gets easy to quickly work through (not to mention some scenarios will be repeated pretty quickly), for some people it might lose its charm rapidly. But for some people, playing through all of the choices and getting to know all of the game's mechanisms and fleshing out attributes for a character might be worth many, many hours of playing.However, a little note on the endings (and this is based on my perception and will not apply to everone): just remember that the endings can be a bit general, as the characters are not special unless you make them be. But despite being general and based on your desicions, the endings are very humbling, human, and profound for what they are.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												A quirky and quaint little game.  The story lines are funny and rather strange, but that makes them interesting.  They can also be unexpectedly dark.  The art is very bright and colourful, and the music, though only two songs, is pleasant.  Most people complain about it being too short (each round is about 10 minutes), although I think it's meant to be that way so you can play multiple rounds quickly, seeing as it can be difficult to save the town when you're still new to the game.  I wish there was more variation, though; once you've played about 10 rounds, you've basically seen everything, and saving the town becomes quite easy.  There are some typos in the game (I think I spotted about two or three), which is a little disappointing given that it's primarily text-based.  Also, I can't seem to run the game in windowed mode, although I know not everyone has this problem.  You can't skip the credits at the end, although they only last about 15 seconds, so I don't think that's a big deal.

It's a very rich choose-your-own adventure and despite the number of times I've played it, I've yet to see the same story twice. Don't get me wrong, this game is SHORT. If you play 4 characters you can finish in about 10-15 minutes, but then you play again and again. The music is bewitching, the design is lovely and the story is your own. The only thing I wish about this game was that it was longer or had more options, only because I want to be immersed longer.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												The Yawgh is a fun "Choose-Your-Own-Adventure"-type game in which you can control 2-4 characters in a town for 6 weeks as well as build up different character stats which also affect the story.What I Did Like: The story was well-written and entertaining, including all the different story options. It's nice they didn't always make it terribly obvious what was going to happen or what stats you would need in order to have a 'successful' result when making a choice. I liked the art and loved the music.What I Didn't Like: Each play-through is pretty quick, even using all 4 characters - about 10-15 minutes. After 45 minutes of playing, I felt I had seen 80% of the "event triggers" if that makes sense, and was ready to play something else for the time being.Overall: I found the game to be really enjoyable as well as relaxing. I experienced maybe half of what the game has to offer, story-wise, and for me this definitely has replay value. Not a bad deal for $10 if you know you like "C-Y-O-A" and an even better deal if you can get it on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												The Yawhg is quite an interesting game; in such a way that it isn't really a game persay. It's an interactive journey. The Yawhg is about the titular event that will happen after 6 weeks, and what it might be is unclear. It's an incredible storyteller, and I got back into it after seeing a kickstarted game named Monster Prom, which is like the cruder little sibling of The Yawhg.Not to say it's bad, but I couldn't help but draw connections.Each week in The Yawhg, each character (up to four characters, controlled by 1-4 people) goes to one location, and raises one of their 6 stats. Then, a random event will happen, and you choose one of two choices, usually requiring certain stats to be successful. This repeats for the 6 weeks, but it's far from dull. The consequent events are impacted by your previous choices, giving a sense of reality and impact to your choices.I won't spoil what happens after The Yawhg, because it's more fun to find out yourself. The game's only $9.99, it's great with friends, and it's bitesized fun at 20-30 minutes per game. Just go buy it, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												A great party filler for when you have a few friends over. It's playable by anybody, has a strong narrative, delightful consequences, and a solid ending all in a short session. While the first time is always the best, it does have some replayability.If the premise tempts you at all, go for it. If you need more specifics, it's a collaborative short story of small choices that build individual character stats and the groups overall stats affect the resolution of the narrative. No reflex based game play, just menu choices for each player. The game shines with how the narratives collaborate and how some choices come back to haunt everyone.Grab four controllers and play up the dramatic sense of impending doom for best effect.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												Nice art direction and sound, fairly well written, but even for a pick your own adventure game it is incredibly short and shallow. Just over 10 minutes to playthrough, I managed to get the good ending easily on my second try. Gameplay is very simple, character can go to a location which will raise two attributes with a choice of raising them slightly less and gaining wealth with an event happening either raising or lowering attributes depending or your choice. Compared to a game like "Long Live The Queen" choices are quite simple, seemingly not measured against attributes and with very little consequence. It's a cute little game, but sadly far too short and simple. Slightly changed it would probably make a good game for young children.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												9/10Very entertaining game. Each play through is relatively short and yes you do get a certain amount of repetition in the endings. However, the writing is amusing and engaging and honestly, so long as you go in looking for a bit of fun you can get hours of playthrough from this. I quite enjoyed that even if you try as hard as you can to get yourself a great ending, something might pop up and ruin everything. Some people might be annoyed that chance plays a factor like this but I think it just adds to the fun. It's great on your own, it's better with friend(s). I would definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys CYOA and has a sense of humour.

												This game is absolutely beautiful. I would recommend this to anyone who has at least one other person that can play with them. I've never played it alone because I feel the point of the game would be missing, but I've had a massively good time just hanging out on my couch with friends and family alike having a wonderful time exploring this world they have created. I have played this game enough to experience every story (or almost every story) but I still play it with people because I love their reaction to playing it for the first few times. It's such a unique experience that you should not pass up. Worth every single penny.

content:
Posted: January 11
												You and your friends know *something* is coming to lay waste to your town in six weeks. You take it in turns to prepare, week by week, honing your skills so that after that *something* happens you will be able to rebuild the life you once had. Or maybe you'll just contract vampirism and die alone. Whatever works for you.I have replayed this game with many different friends and enjoyed their reactions to the unusual scenarios it threw at them, especially when seemingly minor decisions come back to haunt them. It's a very short game but lasts just as long as it needs to. Soundtrack and visual style work perfectly. Only criticism is the lack of online multiplayer.

												Nonlinear choose your own adventure.Each game takes about five minutes. Choose a character, choose parts of the city to explore and make choices about the scenarios you encounter. After six turns the Yawhg arrives, the game ends, and you see the outcome of your choices.Lovely writing, beautiful art by Emily Carroll (who's webcomics I highly recommend), cool mechanic, and enough scenarios for plenty of replayability.I see some posters have suggested you need IRL friends to enjoy the game, but I think it will impress friendless players who enjoy storytelling.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9
The Yawhg is one of those games where you can see great potential for a party setting. When brought into a party setting however, you find plenty of room for laughs all around as each person(or groups of people if you decide to have characters run democratically) encounters the day to day life before encountering the Yawhg. The unpredictable nature of when certain scenarios will occur, and the probability of having correct scores when these great events arise allow for experimentation with each playthrough. The games taking about 20 minutes, this gives the game great versatility in the party setting. I truly recommend this game to anyone who is often looked to as the bringer of party games during grand rendevous, and those who find games that require multiple ways of thinking quite intriguing. So step into the adventure as blue, red, yellow, or green as you prepare for the coming of the Yawhg.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9
												The Yawgh is a fun experience, somewhat similar to a game called Reigns. It's simple enough to play. Choose a location, face an event, make a choice, accept the results, and move on to the next location. These choices change your character, and the town. I've played through the game six times now. I've saved the town and suffered personal tragedy, and watched the town struggle, as I thrived.There are a lot of outcomes in this game, and although they're generally predictable, they can also be surprising. The outcomes can be heroic, humorous or tragic. Although I think I've "won" this game, I'm going to play a few more times just to see how other choices play out.On that note, this isn't the kind of game that you're going to play for over a hundred hours, but that's okay. It's less than the price of a movie ticket, can be enjoyed with friends, and will last you at least a couple of hours if you're willing to explore it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												Quick Review:This game has a nice feel of a short story being told where you control the characters in it. The story (for me) was very dark and I haven't experienced a positive ending yet. I would suggest getting it if you can find it on sale for under $3.00.How I got the game:I bought a bundle from another site with this game included.Full review:The idea behind this game is that something is coming called the Yawhg. It destroyed the town before and you have 6 weeks to prepare for when it returns. This is a choose your own adventure type story that can be played very quickly. You are shown a map where you choose an area to go to then you are given another choice of what to do while you are in that area. You repeat this process using 2 characters for 6 turns. At the end of those turns the Yawhg appears.What I liked:I enjoyed the images and graphics used in the story telling, it really gave the feeling of reading a story from an old book. There are 4 different characters and you got to play as 2 of them for one game. The options for what you can have the characters do are limited but they gave some interesting outcomes. I also liked the music playing in the background, it kept me interested in the game and added to the feel of a story.What I didn't like:The outcomes from the choices I made were pretty much the same when I had different characters play the same sections. The game is very short. I was able to play it through twice in about 20 minutes. I didn't receive good endings and maybe it prevented me from extending the game play but that is what I experienced. There is a lot of build up for the Yawhg story line but the game doesn't deliver when it comes to the actual action of dealing with it.Final Thoughts:I like the game and would suggest getting it if you could find it under $3.00. For me there wasn't enough to spend $9.99 on. The lack of content deterred me from wanting to play it again and see if things could be different using another character in other areas or making various choices with the same characters. I felt that even if I did try the reward wouldn't be worth the effort.Other Notes:Let me know what you thought of the review I wrote. I will be writing and re-writing reviews on games I have already played and games I have yet to play. I'm interested to hear if what I've written is helpful or if there are things that people would like to see. I'm also interested in corrections if I have made a mistake about the details of gameplay.Thank you for reading.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28
												Interesting and different casual choose-your-own-adventure story with multiplayer. Seems fixed at 1280x720 resolution. Some nice art, and unique folk music soundtrack that sets the mood. This is not a good singleplayer game, nor really a good party game if you are seeking thrills. It is however a good game to play with your girlfriend who is not so good at fast-paced or busy action games, but who still wants to play games with you. Recommended if you need a casual non-competitive game to play with someone. But not really for kids unless you are fine with some of the more gruesome and sad outcomes depicted. Not a lot of bells and whistles though. Very niche type of game, also overpriced for what it is. Get on sale, or part of a bundle, maaaybe worth $5 but really more like $3.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 22
												Looked intresting, so i wanted it, But look at that god damn price tag. So i waited until a very loyal friend bought me it.The game gets very repetitive way too quickly, visiting/working at seperate places doesnt seem to effect anything beyond normal gameplay except 2 events, attacked by a werewolf or attacked by a vampire. when these events happen, the day after, no matter what area you are in, you transform into whatever attacked you previously, and you destroy the area you are currently in, making all 4 characters unable to use that area afterwards other than that nothing effects the actual gameplay. you could drink at the tavern all day one day, and still be able to function at other jobs the next. there is no grey area, you either fail after the week ends, or you succeed, and theres only a few ways to succeed, and even fewer ways to fail. For example,  you could hunt animals every day, and then not choose the right job suited for you at the end  of the week, resulting in a failure where your characterdies of starvation due to the ghosts of the animals you hunted warning away any alive animals that you try to catch. its a unique death, but it doesnt result with a special ending or anything. your character dies and thats a failure. it ends the same way as every other death, with you being dead, and no payoff otherwise.you could experiment with several different choices, but in the end, the game falls flat and has no payoff.
